utterances: (SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SPECIAL LADY"")
(Singing) When we fuss and fighting, I can't get no sleep at night.
Well, we're going to play this for him.
So is there anything you would like to say to Isaiah Sharkey?
I would say everything that I've always said to him.
He is truly one of the greatest musicians that I've ever heard or been around.
What he's able to do is to inspire me to go back and practice more.
And I really appreciate him for that because that doesn't happen every day.
You try to practice.
You try to get better.
But then you meet someone who's so gifted that you say - hey, I've got to step up my game even more if I'm even going to stand on the stage next to this man.
So my hat's off to him for real.
Well, Brian McKnight, it's been so great talking to you.
Thank you for this.
Thank you.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SPECIAL LADY"")
(Singing) Baby, you're just a very special lady, a very special lady, very special lady, very special lady.
Girl, I love you.
A very special...
And Isaiah Sharkey is with us now from Chicago.
Happy Thanksgiving.
Oh, happy Thanksgiving to you.
What was it like to hear that from Brian McKnight?
Wow.
My response is just wow.
It's really an honor to hear someone that has that type of gift and that amount of history in being an icon and one of the most talented artists of the last two generations.
How did you get from being a guitar player to being kind of the frontman writing and recording your own music?
I wanted to definitely do my own music and put it out for people to experience.
And I wasn't intending on singing.
My intentions wasn't to sing an entire project because I was so used to playing guitar, and I was known as a guitarist.
But it just so happened the compositions and songs that I was writing required vocals and required lyrics.
And so I felt that it would be really difficult to get some fantastic singers, in my opinion, to tour with me, you know, consistently.
So I said - well, you know, I can hold a note a little bit, so I'll sing.
And it just so happened that things turned out to be pretty good.
And people have taken a liking to it, so I...
Yeah, it turns out you're a pretty great singer.
I'm all right.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""LOVE LIFE LIVE"")
(Singing) Come on, baby.
Give me all you have - have to give, have to give.
Well, Isaiah Sharkey, I want to give you a chance to throw this forward to someone else who you're thankful for on this Thanksgiving Day.
Yes.
I am actually thankful for a artist here from Chicago.
Her name is Aniba Hotep, and she has a group called The Sol Collective.
S-O-L.
Yes.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""SWEET THANG"")
(Singing) Love me now, or I'll go crazy - oh, sweet thang.
She is absolutely incredible.
Her lyrics touch on a lot of different subjects, from being in love to social issues to - just everything you can possibly think of, she writes about.
And I admire that about her.
And she's a incredible singer as well.
She can give you a Aretha Franklin type of thing, but she can also give you a Carole King type of vibe, you know...
Wow.
(Singing) She say a lot of things.
Oh, what she say?
The kind of things that cause you pain.
She kind of hoping that you don't see.
She went from just your friend to your beginning and your end.
And you couldn't object 'cause you can't remember agreeing.
What do you get from listening to this?
Well, you can hear all of her influences, you know?
She's influenced by Prince.
She's also influenced by all of the great female vocalists of soul music, but she also listens to Sting.
She listens to David Bowie.
You know, she has her own version of her gumbo.
(LAUGHTER)
And I love artists that take all of their musical experiences and somehow they're able to marry all of those different experiences together.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""GIRLZ LIKE HER"")
(Singing) Girls like her don't play with circumstances.
Girls like her don't fly with chances.
Well, we're going to play this for her.
So what would you like to say to her on this Thanksgiving Day?
Aniba, you are absolutely fantastic.
I love your energy.
I love your music, and I look forward to doing more work with you.
And I look forward to the world hearing what you have to offer.
Well, Isaiah Sharkey, thank you for spending this time with us today.
And happy Thanksgiving.
Thank you.
Happy Thanksgiving to you.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""GIRLZ LIKE HER"")
(Singing) For girls like her, growing up and real love just ain't enough, oh.
Girls like her, they think they stay...
And Aniba Hotep is with us now.
Hi, there.
Hello.
How are you?
I'm doing great.
Thanks.
What was it like for you to hear that just now?
You know, it's high praise.
Sharkey is definitely a Chicago musical hero.
He's such a example of everything that is possible when you pursue what you love.
And he's such an exceptional talent that when you get his attention, you always feel, like, really special.
Other people might not admit that.
I have no problems admitting it.
You know, Sharkey said something to me - I'm like, I'm a genius because Sharkey.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""GIRLZ LIKE HER"")
(Singing) And she won't hesitate to play that game and change the picture, change that frame and make him think he's living a life of his creation.
He talked about your sound and your influences.
And there were a whole lot of names there, from Aretha to Prince to Sting and Carole King, David Bowie and on and on and on.
Tell us about your influences and where your sound comes from.
Well, I'm originally from Virginia and from a small town.
And there wasn't an urban radio station, so I learned and was fed a lot of the Eagles and The Doors...
Wow.
...And Jefferson Airplane and a lot of what people call heartland rock, but I also grew up in a Baptist church - so all of those influences.
I'm also a child of hip-hop.
But as I got older, I got more exposure to jazz.
And then, you know, in college, all of the psychedelic, like, '60s rock and trip-hop and drum-and-bass from the U.K.
That is a lot.
That is a lot in the melting pot.
Is there a song of yours that you can point us to that kind of shows that mashup in action?
